Graphical abstract Direct conversion of methanol and acetic acid (HAc) into acrylic acid (AA) and methyl acrylate (MA) is remarkably significant for the high-value utilization of coal-based chemicals. However, the previous catalysts, due to their single function or poor synergy between multiple active sites, remain large challenges in direct synthesis of acrylic acid. Herein, we designed a novel catalyst system through coating TiO2 to sodium superionic conductor (NASICON) substrate for direct synthesis of acrylic acid from methanol and acetic acid. It was revealed that the catalyst with TiO2 coating showed obviously improved performance. The selectivity of AA+MA highly reached 56.1 % at 380 °C, corresponding to the spatiotemporal yield of 46.5 μmol·g−1·min−1. It was demonstrated that TiO2 coating catalyzes the oxidative dehydrogenation of methanol to formaldehyde, while NASICON substrate exerts important effects on the aldol condensation of formaldehyde and acetic acid, and their effective synergy promotes the direct synthesis of acrylic acid. Keywords Acrylic acid Acetic acid Methanol NASICON TiO2 Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Acrylic acid (AA) and its derivatives are important monomers for the synthesis of polymers, and widely applied in coatings, adhesives, etc. [1]. The current main technology for acrylic acid production is a two-step process of propylene oxidation. Here, propylene is derived from petroleum, the price of which is increasing due to the depletion of global petroleum resources; moreover, the market demand of acrylic acid also increases rapidly. Thus, there is a great urgency to develop some new/optional acrylic acid production technologies, such as the biomass routes for lactic acid dehydration [2] and glycerol oxidation [3], the coal-based routes for aldol condensation of methanol/formaldehyde and acetic acid, etc. Thereinto, the technologies for methanol/formaldehyde (FA) and acetic acid (HAc) condensation are very promising considering the regions with abundant coal resources and serious overcapacity of methanol and acetic acid production. In previous reports, coal-based route is mainly focused on the synthesis of acrylic acid from formaldehyde and acetic acid, which has made significant progress in the understanding of related catalytic systems. However, this pathway has some technical difficulties. Since formaldehyde, as an irritant and toxic gas, is chemically active and easy to polymerize, it can be only stored and transported in a low concentration aqueous solution. Moreover, when formaldehyde aqueous solution as raw material is used to synthesize acrylic acid, a large amount of water appended into the system will lead to poor activity due to its preferential adsorption on the active site as well as severe generation of wastewater [4]. In contrast, if methanol and acetic acid are used to directly synthesize acrylic acid, not only the reaction process is shortened, but also methanol is safer and more stable than formaldehyde. Therefore, the direct synthesis of acrylic acid from methanol and acetic acid, which are serious overcapacity, is a very promising technical route. The direct synthesis of acrylic acid from methanol and acetic acid involves a multi-step cascade process containing dehydrogenation and aldol condensation, etc. This requires the use of catalyst with redox sites and acid-base sites. However, these two active sites can also catalyze other reactions within the system, making the reaction system complex, which in turn leads to poor productivity of acrylic acid and methyl acetic(MA) [5,6]. As listed in the Scheme 1 , esterification and aldol condensation reactions occur smoothly at acidic sites. This leads to the yield of a series of compounds, such as acetic acid methyl ester, dimethyl ether, acrylic acid, and its esters. Meanwhile, at the redox sites, oxidation and peroxidation reactions also take place, leading to the production of formaldehyde, methyl formate, and carbon oxides (COx). Due to the enormous challenge, only a few studies have ever reported the direct synthesis of acrylic acid from methanol and acetic acid so far. Shen et al. demonstrated that the synergy between methanol dehydrogenation on superficial V species and aldol condensation on the acid-base sites is the key to achieve the direct synthesis, obtaining 28 % selectivity of AA+MA through conversion of methanol and acetic acid [7]. Recently, Chen et al. realized direct conversion of methanol and methyl acetate into high value-added esters/aldehydes by adjusting the spatial distance and bed distribution between Cu active sites and Cs active sites with methanol and methyl acetate as feedstock. However, when methanol and acetic acid were used as the reactants, they found that most of the products were methyl acetate, suggesting that esterification is easier to occur than methanol dehydrogenation [8]. Therefore, constructing the catalysts with dehydrogenation and aldol condensation activities that are well synergized is essential to achieve direct synthesis of acrylic acid. During our review of the literature, we noticed that there is such a sodium super ion conductor (NASICON) material with phosphate structure, which performs well in alcohol dehydrogenation reactions [9,10]. Mitran et al. have revealed that 100 % selectivity of formaldehyde was obtained with 50 % conversion of methanol on the H1-xTi2(PO4)3-x(SO4)x NASICON materials [11,12]. They demonstrated that good dehydrogenation ability is related to the presence of Ti3+/Ti4+ ions pair and acidic sites on the surface. Early, Ai et al demonstrated that phosphate structures are effective for aldol condensation because they can provide abundant acid-based sites [13–17]. We previously applied NASICON materials to the synthesis of acrylic acid and methyl acrylate from formaldehyde and acetic acid. It was demonstrated that the generation of AA+MA is favored by tuning the acid-base properties on the catalyst surface as well as the phase composition of NASICON (H1-xTi2(PO4)3-x(SO4)x) material [18–20]. Moreover, it further confirmed the previous understanding of the acid-base catalytic mechanism. Specifically, the Brønsted acidic sites (BAS) on the catalyst are used to promote the adsorption of reactants and the activation of formaldehyde, while the Lewis acidic sites (LAS) are mainly responsible for the activation of acetic acid [21]; moreover, the basic sites are more inclined to cleave α-H in acetic acid molecular and thus promote aldol condensation [13,22]. From the above progress, NASICON material possesses bi-functionality of redox and aldol condensation, which might potentially catalyze condensation of methanol and acetic acid to acrylic acid. Previously, we have attempted to use the NASICON material for direct synthesis of acrylic acid from methanol and acetic acid. Unfortunately, the NASICON material showed poor performance. It was found that our prepared NASICON could not well drive the dehydrogenation of methanol to intermedium formaldehyde, thereby leading to the result that the subsequent condensation step does not well proceed. Therefore, in order to realize the direct synthesis of acrylic acid from methanol and acetic acid, it is essential to construct redox sites on NASICON substrate, which can well match with the active sites for aldol condensation. Some studies have found that TiO2 itself has a good redox capacity due to its variable valence [23]. Takashi et al. found that TiO2 can catalyze oxidation of 2-propanol to acetone at 250 °C [24]. Nie et al noted that TiO2 and TiO2-SiO2 materials can catalyze styrene oxidation into benzaldehyde [25]. Herein, in this paper, we have fabricated a series of TiO2-coated NASICON (with different Ti/P ratios, such as NSC-Ti/P-0.5, NSC-Ti/P-0.6, NSC-Ti/P-0.7) bi-functional catalysts and applied them for direct synthesis of acrylic acid from methanol and acetic acid. Catalytic behaviors as well as the physicochemical properties were in-detail investigated. With synergistic effect of redox and acid-base properties, the selectivity of AA + MA reached 56.1 % (based on acetic acid input) over the catalyst with TiO2 coating, corresponding to the spatiotemporal yield (STY) of 46.5 μmol·g−1 min−1. 2 Experimental 2.1 Experimental reagents Methanol (CH3OH 99 %) from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd.; glacial acetic acid (CH3COOH 99.5 %) from Tianjin Beichen District Fangzheng Reagent Factory; titanium oxide sulfate-sulfate hydrate (TiOSO4·xH2SO4·xH2O, 93 %) from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd.; hydrogen peroxide aqueous solution (H2O2 30 %) from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.; polyethylene glycol bisphenol A epichlorohydrin copolymer (HO(CH2CH2O)nH (PEG) 98 %) from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd.; phosphoric acid (H3PO4 85 %, analytical grade) from Tianjin Beichen District Fangzheng Reagent Factory; Tetrabutyl titanate (C16H36O4Ti 98 %, chemically pure) from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.; ammonia (NH3·H2O 25 ∼ 18 %, analytically pure) from Tianjin Fengchuan Chemical Reagent Technology Co., Ltd.; tetraethyl orthosilicate(C8H20O4Si) from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd.; P25 TiO2 from Evonik Degussa. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 NASICON synthesis NASICON materials were synthesized by the sol–gel method, and the synthesis method was described as the literature [26]. Taking the catalyst with Ti/P of 0.6 as an example, where, 0.6 represented molar ratio of Ti/P in synthetic parent liquid. In a typical synthesis, 17.6 g of TiOSO4·xH2SO4·yH2O powder was added into appropriate amount of water under magnetic stirring, followed by adding 22.9 g H2O2 aqueous solution, continuously stirring for 2 hours (h). Simultaneously, 7.6 g PEG was added into appropriate amount of water to gain another solution. The above two solutions were mixed completely, stirring vigorously for 1 h. Afterward, 14.6 g of H3PO4 solution (85 wt%) was added dropwise into the above solution, continuously stirring for 2 h. The resulting foamy-like solution was dried at 60 °C in an oven for 2 days. Finally, NASICON material was obtained by calcining dry gel at 600 °C for 10 h, and named as NSC-Ti/P-0.6. Other single NASICON materials (NSC-Ti/P-xs) were also prepared by similar method with the above, only changing Ti/P ratios in parent solutions (x represents the molar ratio of Ti/P). 2.2.2 Preparation of NSC-TiO2 catalyst TiO2 coating procedure was referred to the literature [27]. Taking NSC-Ti/P-0.6-TiO2-0.075 catalyst as an example: 5 g of above-prepared NSC-Ti/P-0.6 was placed into 100 mL of anhydrous ethanol, followed by adding 0.3 mL of ammonia with sonication for 15 min. Then, 1.60 g of tetrabutyl titanate (TBOT) was added into the above mixed solution drop-by-drop, stirring at 45 °C for 24 h. The resulting suspension was centrifuged. Finally, the catalyst was obtained through drying and further roasting at 500 °C for 2 h. The collected samples were named as NAC-Ti/P-x-TiO2-y, where y was defined as the weight ratio of TiO2 to NASICON materials. 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the catalysts were characterized on a Bruker Advance X-ray D8 diffractometer in the 2θ range of 10-80◦ under Cu Kα radiation (40 kV, 15 mA). The textural parameters were obtained on the acquisition technique of specific surface area and pore volume analyzer (type JW-BK100 from JWGB SCI); wherein, the specific surface area was calculated using Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) model and the pore size distribution was calculated using Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model. The x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) characterization was performed on a Thermo Fisher ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer equipped with an Al-k-α monochromated flood source. The binding energy (BE) was calibrated against the C1s signal (284.8 eV) of contaminant carbon. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were taken on a JSM-7900F SEM. High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images were taken on a JEM-2100F field emission transmission electron microscope. The acidity and basicity of the catalysts were determined on programmed temperature rise desorption TP5080 instrument by using programmed temperature rise desorption of NH3 and CO2 (NH3-TPD, CO2-TPD), respectively. For NH3-TPD test, 0.1 g of catalyst was treated at 300 °C for 30 min to remove the possible adsorbed impurities, and then cooled down to 100 °C. Subsequently the sample was saturated in flowing NH3 atmosphere for 15 min. After that, the programed temperature rise was conducted by heating to 600 °C and desorption signal was recorded by the thermo-conductive detector (TCD). CO2-TPD operation was similar with that of NH3-TPD, only replacing NH3 with CO2. Pyridine infrared spectroscopy (Py-IR) was used to identify the acidic site type. Simply, the sample was pressed into self-supporting wafer; then the wafer was mounted inside vacuum cell with CaF2 window pool and degassed at 300 °C for 3 h. After cooling down to room temperature, the IR spectrum was recorded on Bruker tensor 27 spectrometer, being regarded as the background. Thereafter, pyridine was introduced to the system and exposed the sample for 15 min. Finally, the IR spectra were recorded after evacuation at 150 °C for 1 h. In-situ DRIFT experiment was conducted on a Bruker Tensor 27 FT-IR spectrometer in the range of 4000∼800 cm−1. The catalyst powder was placed into an in-situ IR cell. Prior to each measurement, the powder was firstly heated at 380 °C for 60 min under argon(Ar) flow to remove physically adsorbed impurities. The spectrum was recorded as the background. Then, acetic acid was carried into system by Ar flow, absorbing for 30 min. The spectrum was recorded until the intensity of the vibrational peak was stable. After that, the system was purged with Ar stream; simultaneously, the spectra were recorded each minute to monitor the adsorption changes. Methanol DRIFT experiment was similar with the above, whereas acetic acid was replaced by methanol and Ar was switched to air. In order to distinguish the vibrational bands of gas-phase species from those of adsorbed species [28], KBr, as a reference, was used to perform DRIFT experiments for methanol/acetic acid. Here, the operation is similar with that on the catalyst, except for replacing the catalyst with KBr powder. The collected spectra were compared with those on the catalysts. 2.4 Catalyst evaluation The acrylic acid synthesis from methanol and acetic acid was carried out in a fixed-bed glass-tube reactor filled with 2 g of catalyst (20–40 mesh). Fig. 1 a and b shows the activities of the catalysts with different Ti/P ratios (NSC-Ti/P-xs) and amount of TiO2 coating (NSC-Ti/P-x-TiO2-y). It is observed that NSC-Ti/P-xs (NSC-Ti/P-0.5, NSC-Ti/P-0.6, NSC-Ti/P-0.7) show relatively poor performance, wherein selectivity of AA+MA slightly increases with increase of Ti/P ratio. Our previous research revealed that single NASICON material was able to well catalyze condensation of formaldehyde and acetic acid to acrylic acid [19]. Based on two-step process of this reaction, the present results seemingly indicate that the dehydrogenation is not disabled on single NSC-Ti/P-xs, reversely, esterification reaction between methanol and acetic acid easily occurs on them, leading to the formation of lots of methyl acetate. When the methyl acetate is considered as the unreacted acetic acid for calculation (according to Eq. (4)), the selectivity of AA+MA appears to be improved due to the deduction of part of conversion (Fig. 1a and b). Thus, the NSC-Ti/P-xs give around 25 % selectivity of AA+MA. For the catalysts with TiO2 coating, selectivity of AA+MA and STY are greatly improved as shown in Fig. 1a and b, despite of little changed conversion. Especially on NSC-Ti/P-0.6-TiO2-0.075, selectivity of AA+MA (according to Eq. (4)) increases to 50.9 % from 27.9 % on NSC-Ti/P-0.6 and correspondingly the STY reaches 33.1 μmol·g−1·min−1. The above strongly indicates that these coated catalysts have possessed redox and aldol condensation activities, which successfully catalyze condensation of methanol and acetic acid into acrylic acid and methyl acrylate. In addition, pure TiO2 prepared by us through the hydrolysis of n-butyl titanate was further used for direct synthesis of acrylic acid. Through analysis on the collected products, acrylic acid and methyl acrylate were hardly detected in the liquid products, even though acetic acid was completely converted. Instead, a significant quantity of oil-like substances (including about 50 substances, such as ketones, alcohols, esters, alkenes, phenols, aromatic compounds, etc.) were produced, as displayed in Figure S1. Additionally, a large number of alkanes (mainly methane) and hydrogen were found in gaseous products. Besides, the physical mixture of TiO2 and NASICON (Ti/P = 0.6) was used for conversion of methanol and acetic acid. As shown in Figure S2, the physically-mixed catalyst shows a certain improvement of performance compared to the single NASICON, whereas it is still not as good as that on TiO2-coated catalyst. This indicates that the shorter distance between the active sites is more conducive to the cascade process due to their good matching. For the present catalysis system, expect the main routes for methyl acetate, acrylic acid and methyl acrylate formation, there are multiple competing reaction pathways. The by-products formed on the presentative catalysts are listed in Table S1. As observed, small amounts of acrolein, dimethyl ether (DME), and the trace of other by-products are formed in the liquid products, while the gas-phase by-products are mainly comprised of COx (CO, CO2), dimethyl ether (DME), methane, ethane, ethylene, propylene, C4+ olefin and small amount of the uncondensed methyl formate (MF). Also noting that the amount of formed formaldehyde obviously increase on the TiO2-coated catalysts, especially NSC-Ti/P-0.6-TiO2-0.075. As shown in Scheme 1, the synthesis of acrylic acid and methyl acrylate from methanol and acetic acid involves dehydrogenation and aldol condensation. Some intermediates formed by dehydrogenation of methanol are also present in products. Despite air was used for the present reaction, small amount of hydrogen is still detected at the outlet. It is deduced that intermediates and products are probably hydrogenated to corresponding by-products such as acrolein. The formation of a minute quantity of hydrocarbon products should be related with decarboxylation/decarboxylation of oxy-compound and further polymerization. Based on the amounts of all of products, we calculated the carbon balance, as tabulated in Table S2. It reveals that the carbon balance is substantially 90 % above. Fig. 1d shows that there is a significant effect on the catalytic activity with increase of TiO2 coating amount. The selectivity of AA+MA as well as the STY of the target products (AA+MA) is inclined to increase and then decrease with the increase of the TiO2 coating amount. Simultaneously the esterification of methanol-acetic acid is weakened. The catalyst with 0.075 TiO2 coating is the most effective. In addition, conversion data for methanol in different reaction routes have also been listed in Table S3. It is observed that most of the methanol is converted into methyl acetate and dimethyl ether beside AA and MA. 3.1.2 Effect of reaction conditions 3.1.2.1 Feed ratio of methanol and acetic acid (HAc) Condensation reactions with different feed ratio of methanol and acetic acid were operated at 380 °C and LHSV = 1.5 mL·g−1·h−1. The results are shown in Fig. 2 a. As observed, the acetic acid conversion increases slightly with the elevated feed ratio of methanol and acetic acid. However, the selectivity of AA+MA firstly increases and then declines with feed ratio decrease from 1:1 to 2.5:1, wherein the highest selectivity (50.9 %) is achieved with the feed ratio of 2:1. It is thought that the higher ratio of methanol easily provides more probability of reaction with acetic acid through esterification and the formation of more formaldehyde on the surface of the catalyst. However, further increase in ratio of methanol probably leads to the coverage of a large proportion of active sites by methanol or its intermediate, thus, acetic acid molecules are difficult to participate in reaction. Reversely, the formation of DME is enhanced. Otherwise, when the ratio of acetic acid is improved, the adsorption of methanol is affected due to the occupation of a lot of acetic acid molecules on the catalyst surface, where the decomposition of acetic acid is enhanced. What shows up is an increase in acetic acid conversion and decrease in selectivity of AA+MA. The STY of AA+MA shows similar trend with the selectivity. In addition, it is seen from Table S4 that the ratio of methanol/HAc also affects the product distribution. Due to increase of ratio of methanol/HAc, the esterification reaction is enhanced, which is indicated by the increased selectivity of methyl acetate. Meanwhile, COx selectivity decreases with the increase of feed ratio of methanol/HAc, probably attributing to insufficient oxygen supply. Though other products are also formed, the regularity is not very good due to their low selectivity. 3.1.2.2 Temperature The performance as a function of temperature is shown in Fig. 2b. Condensation reaction was operated at methanol/HAc = 2:1 and LHSV = 1.5 mL·g−1·h−1 . The results show that acetic acid conversion gradually increases with the elevation of reaction temperature, while the selectivity of acrylic acid and methyl acrylate reaches a maximum at 380 °C. In our previous study, it was demonstrated that 360 °C is optimal temperature for aldol condensation of formaldehyde and acetic acid. The present optimal temperature of 380 °C is affected by one that methanol might be effectively dehydrogenated on TiO2 coating at this temperature. As the temperature of the reaction continuously rises to 390 °C, the cracking for the reactants or products might be enhanced, resulting in decrease in the selectivity of AA+MA. From Table S4, it is seen that the conversion of acetic acid decreases and the selectivity of methyl acetate slightly decreases with the increase of temperature when calculated using Eqs. (2) and (4). Probably, the increase in temperature inhibits the esterification reaction between methanol and acetic acid and accelerates the hydrolysis of methyl acetate. Overall, the pathway for conversion of acetic acid to methyl acetate is somewhat suppressed, leading to the decrease of its conversion. For the formaldehyde, as the temperature increases, the selectivity firstly increases and then decreases. This is because the increase of the temperature promotes the dehydrogenation of methanol. However, further increase of the temperature induces the pyrolysis of formaldehyde or the reaction with other substances, indicated in Table S4. Otherwise, as the temperature increases, over-oxidation of the substances in the system is enhanced, leading to increase of COx quantity. 3.1.2.3 LHSV In order to understand the effect of liquid hourly space velocity (LHSV), the experiment was conducted under the following condition: methanol/HAc feed ratio = 2:1, 380 °C and the evaluation results are shown in Fig. 2c. The conversion of acetic acid decreases with the increase of LHSV, whereas the selectivity of AA+MA firstly increases and then decreases. Generally speaking, the higher the LHSV is, the shorter the contact time between the reactants and the active sites on the catalyst surface is. Thus, the incompletely activated reactants or intermediates are taken out of the catalytic system before entering the next reaction step, leading to the decrease in the selectivity of AA+MA and the conversion of acetic acid. From the Table S4, as LHSV increases, the AA+MA selectivity firstly increases and then decreases, whereas the selectivity of methyl acetate gradually increases. Compared with the direct synthesis of acrylic acid from methanol acetic acid, the esterification between methanol acetic acid is much easier. As a result, more reactants participate in the esterification as the contact time increases. Reversely, with the increase of LHSV, COx selectivity decreases rapidly, implying that the reactions for excessive oxidation are suppressed. Due to easy polymerization of formaldehyde, its selectivity is irregular. The total selectivity of AA, MA, methyl acetate, formaldehyde and COx accounts for around 85 %. Therefore, for the present system, esterification, dehydrogenation of methanol to formaldehyde, excessive oxidation are mainly competing reaction routes. In spite of LHSV variation, the selectivity of methyl formate and acrolein is low and slightly changes, thereby being considered as secondary products. Additionally, with the increase of LHSV, it is also noted that methanol tends to undergo dehydration to produce dimethyl ether (contained in “others” in Table S4), whereas the amount of formaldehyde formed decreases accordingly. 3.1.2.4 Airflow rate For present reaction, co-fed air plays an important effect on oxidation of methanol into formaldehyde, which easily facilitates for subsequent aldol condensation. Therefore, the reactions were further performed by changing the fed airflow rate and the results are shown in Fig. 2d. As observed, the conversion of acetic acid gradually increases with the increase of airflow rate, and the selectivity of AA+MA reaches the maximum value (56.1 %) with the airflow rate of 50.0 mL·min−1, corresponding to the STY of 46.5 μmol·g−1·min−1. Further increasing airflow rate to 60.0 mL·min−1 leads to a decrease in the selectivity of AA+MA. In combination with the increase of COx content in products, it is thought that the reactions for excessive oxidation of the reactants intermediates and products have occurred. It is seen from Table S4 that when Eqs. (2) and (4) were used for calculation, the selectivity of methyl acetate decreases partly with the increase of airflow rate. We deduce that the increased rate of oxygen supply is prone to promote oxidation process, thus inhibiting the esterification reaction to a certain extent. The above indicates that air atmosphere plays crucial roles in methanol dehydrogenation and excessive oxidation of other intermediates and products. Besides, the co-fed air also has a significant effect on the removal of carbon, which is a main reason for catalyst deactivation [18–20]. 3.2 Catalyst characterization 3.2.1 Effect of TiO2 coating on structural morphology The XRD patterns of the prepared samples are shown in Fig. 3 . According to the literature [26], the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 14.6°, 20.8°, 24.5°, 29.6°, 33.2° are typical NASICON phase characteristic peaks (PDF # 35 - 0754), while the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 22.6°, 25.3° are attributed to Ti2P2O7 phase (PDF # 38 - 1468). From Fig. 3a, Ti/P ratio greatly affects crystallinity of the prepared NASICON materials. With the decrease of Ti/P ratio, the diffraction peaks ascribed to NASICON phase are obviously weakened, indicating the decreased crystallinity. It is noteworthy that XRD patterns of NSC-Ti/P-0.5 catalyst give predominantly characteristic peaks of Ti2P2O7, accompanied by the presence of few NASICON phase. Further noting, after introducing TiO2 coating, the characteristic peaks ascribed to NASICON phase are weakened. There is no TiO2 characteristic peak observed, indicating its uniform dispersion on the catalyst. Fig. 3b reveals that the NASICON characteristic peaks become wide as the amount of TiO2 coating increase, probably due to the coverage of TiO2. Shown in Fig. 4 are HRTEM images of the as-prepared samples. Wherein, the lattice spacing of 0.321 nm and 0.394 nm is attributed to the (721) and (600) crystal planes of TiP2O7, that of 0.363 nm and 0.373 nm is attributed to the (113) and (620) crystal planes of NASICON, and that of 0.263 nm and 0.337 nm is attributed to the (130) and (120) crystal planes of TiO2 (PDF#53 - 0619). From Fig. 4a, NSC-Ti/P-0.5 sample shows the mixed crystal structure of TiP2O7 phase and NASICON phase. SEM results (Figure S3) also reveal that tiny crystals are formed after coating TiO2. With increase of Ti/P ratio, NASICON phase structure is aggregated (Fig. 4b and c), which is consistent with the XRD results. For the coated samples, TiO2 film is observed on the out sphere of the catalysts. In our previous literature [18,19], it was noted that the presence of mixed crystals (NASICON and Ti2P2O7) can factually modulate the acid − base amount, strength and distribution on the catalyst. The good synergistic effects between the acidic and basic sites are favorable for aldol condensation reactions between formaldehyde and acetic acid, simultaneously suppressing the side reactions. Therefore, the mixed crystal components on present catalysts, in spite of coating TiO2, should exert positive effects on condensation. Figure S4 gives N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and pore size distribution of the as-prepared catalysts. It is seen that all of samples show type IV isotherms and typical H3-type hysteresis loops, indicating the presence of a certain mesoporous structure on them. Pore distribution plots (Fig. S4b) further indicate that these catalysts have similar pore size, whereas the pore structure becomes underdeveloped. No obvious adsorption platform in the hysteresis ring reveals that the pore structure of the catalysts is very irregular and some flat slit structure or wedge structure probably exists. From textural properties in Table 1 , the specific surface area and the pore volume increase after the coating of TiO2, probably ascribed to the loose and porous structure caused by the introduction of TiO2 coating. Our previous researches have indicated that the acrylic acid formation is not closely related to textural properties [19]. However, considering the difference in surface area of the catalysts, acrylic acid formation rate based on specific surface area was calculated (by dividing the specific surface area by STY) and the results are shown in Table S5. For the catalysts with Ti/P ratios of 0.5 and 0.6, TiO2 introduction obviously promotes the formation of acrylic acid and methyl acrylate. In the case of the ones with Ti/P ratio of 0.7, nevertheless, single NSC-Ti/P-0.7 gives the highest AA+MA formation rate, attributing to its smallest specific surface area. The acrylic acid formation rate per surface area over NSC-Ti/P-0.7-TiO2-0.075 is actually decreased because TiO2 introduction induces obvious increase of surface area. Comparing all TiO2-coated catalysts, the one with Ti/P ratio of 0.6 still shows relatively higher acrylic acid productivity. 3.2.2 Adsorption mode of coatings by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) In previous reports, it was mentioned that the difference in the type and number of phosphates severely affected the chemical environment of Ti on the catalyst surface [23]. Here, XPS technique was utilized to characterize the prepared catalysts, and the binding energy (BE) was corrected according to the BE of C1s (284.8 eV). Fig. 5 a and c give XPS spectra of Ti2p on the catalysts, wherein the BEs at 466 and 460 eV are attributed to Ti2p1/2 and Ti2p3/2, respectively [30] The shoulder-like BE at 459 eV corresponds to Ti3+ species [31]. From Fig. 5a and c, the BEs of Ti2p shift to a high position slightly as the Ti/P ratio increases, which is consistent with the previously reported finding [19]. Nevertheless, the Ti2p BEs shift to a lower value after coating TiO2, implying the presence of more defects or low-valence Ti species, such as Ti3+ on the surface. The XPS spectra of Ti2p were further fitted. As shown in Fig. 5b and d, Ti2p XPS spectra are deconvoluted into four peaks. The corresponding Ti3+/(Ti3++Ti4+) ratios as well as the relative percentages of Ti4+ and Ti3+ were calculated, as listed in Table S6. It is found that the percentage of Ti3+ increases after coating TiO2, indicating that the chemical environment of Ti element has changed. It might be because Ti component in TiO2 has interaction with elements on the surface of NASICON material, as indicated by the shift of the peak position of Ti element to lower binding energy [32]. Factually, the improved performance after coating TiO2 also confirms that the enhancement of the redox properties of the catalyst is related to the chemical environment of the Ti element [23]. In the perspective of removal of carbon deposit, moderate ratio of Ti3+/Ti4+ has a positive effect due to its redox property. This phenomenon corresponds to the results of evaluation and characterization, i.e., the catalyst NSC-Ti/P-0.6-TiO2-0.075 has the best catalytic activity for acrylic acid and formaldehyde formation. Fig. 6 a and b show the O1s XPS spectra of NSC-Ti/P-x and NSC-Ti/P-0.6-TiO2-y. There are three types of oxygen species observed on the catalyst surface, in which the oxygen species with BE located near 531 eV are lattice oxygen species(Oα), the ones located near 532 eV are chemisorbed oxygen species (Oβ), and the ones located near 533 eV are hydroxyl oxygen species (Oγ) [33]. As indicated, surface adsorbed oxygen species have a certain relationship with oxygen vacancies. That is, more adsorbed oxygen content (Oβ+Oγ) means the presence of more oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface, which is closely related to redox properties of the catalyst [34]. From the fitting results in Table S7, the surface oxygen concentration slightly increases with the increase of Ti/P ratio. However, introduction of TiO2 somewhat induces a decrease in the surface oxygen concentration. Based on the fitted results of the O1s XPS spectra, the percentage of the Oα is higher than other two oxygen species (Oβ and Oγ) and declines after coating TiO2, whereas Oβ content increases obviously. The catalyst NSC-Ti/P-0.6-TiO2-0.075 has the highest adsorbed oxygen content, meaning that it should behave the best redox performance, being just consistent with the catalytic test results. With respect to BEs of P2s, no change is found on the catalysts before and after introduction of TiO2 coating (Figure S5). 3.2.3 Acid-base properties of the catalysts The condensation of methanol and acetic acid involves the oxidation of methanol to formaldehyde and the aldol condensation of formaldehyde and acetic acid. As pointed out in previous studies [21,22], the aldol condensation reaction can be catalyzed by acidity or basicity. Thus, it is important to investigate the acid-base properties of the catalyst [19–21,35]. Here the NSC-Ti/P-x-TiO2-y catalysts were characterized by NH3-TPD, CO2-TPD and Py-IR techniques. NH3-TPD . Fig. 7 gives the NH3-TPD profiles for NSC-Ti/P-x-TiO2-y catalysts, and the calculated amounts of acid-base sites are listed in Table 2 . From Fig. 7, all of the catalysts show similar desorption curves in the form of broad peaks located in range of 100–500 °C. In Fig. 7a, the area of desorption peak firstly increases and then decreases when the ratio of Ti/P increases from 0.5 to 0.7 before and after introduction of TiO2 coating. NSC-Ti/P-0.6-TiO2-0.075 catalyst has the largest peak area, as indicated in Table 2. Further comparing the NH3-TPD results of the NSC-Ti/P-0.6-TiO2-y catalysts, the amounts of acidic sites do not monotonically increase or decrease when the amounts of the TiO2 coating increase, where the largest amounts of total acidic sites are still presented on NSC-Ti/P-0.6-TiO2-0.075. CO2-TPD . CO2-TPD plots of the prepared catalysts are shown in Fig. 8 , where the desorption peaks at about 180 °C and 390 °C correspond to the weak basic sites and the strong basic sites, respectively. From Fig. 8a, NSC-Ti/P-0.5 sample shows a few weak basic sites and abundant medium-strong basic sites, whereas the percentage of the latter obviously decreases with the increase of Ti/P ratio. Over the NSC-Ti/P-0.7, medium-strong basic sites are hardly observed. In the case of TiO2-coated catalysts, the total amounts of basic sites increase to the extent (Table 2), whereas, that of medium-strong basic sites decrease certainly, probably ascribed to the coverage of TiO2. We further performed CO2-TPD on the catalysts with different amount of TiO2 coating (NSC-Ti/P-0.6-TiO2-y). As depicted in Table 2, the total amounts of basic sites slowly increase and then sharply decrease with the increase of TiO2 coating. Apparently, NSC-Ti/P-0.6-TiO2-0.075 catalyst has the most basic sites. Py-IR. The type of acidic sites was identified using FTIR spectroscopy with pyridine as the probe molecule. Fig. 9 gives the pyridine adsorption infrared spectra (Py-IR) of the catalysts before and after coating TiO2. Here, the vibration peaks at 1540 cm−1 are ascribed to pyridine adsorption on BAS, the ones at 1450 cm−1 are associated with pyridine adsorption on LAS, and the ones at 1490 cm−1 are related to pyridine co-adsorption on LAS and BAS [36–38]. From Fig. 9, the uncoated NSC-Ti/P-xs show relatively weak intensity of the peaks for pyridine adsorption, wherein, NSC-Ti/P-0.7 shows the weakest vibration peak for pyridine adsorption, which is similar with NH3-TPD results. However, after introduction of TiO2, the peaks ascribed to BAS and LAS are intensified, especially for LAS, the enhancement is remarkably obvious. The B/L (BAS/LAS) ratio was calculated, as shown in Table S8. In combination of the evaluation results, it is apparent that the B/L ratio of the catalyst with Ti/P ratio of 0.6 is moderate value suitable for aldol condensation [18]. According to the results of NH3-TPD, CO2-TPD and Py-IR, coating TiO2 strongly affects the acid-base properties of the catalyst as well as changes the chemical environment of Ti elements. On the NSC-Ti/P-0.6-TiO2-0.075 catalyst, the largest number of total acidic and total basic sites are presented, which justly corresponds to its best catalytic activity for direct synthesis of acrylic acid and methyl acrylate. Considering possible effects of introduction of TiO2 on aldol condensation, the catalysts with or without TiO2 coating were used to catalyze condensation of formaldehyde and acetic acid to acrylic acid respectively. From Table S9, single NSC-Ti/P-0.6 catalyst shows 77.5 % selectivity of AA+MA, corresponding to the STY of 57.6 μmol·g−1·min−1. However, on the NSC-Ti/P-0.6-TiO2-0.075 catalyst, the selectivity declines to 66.2 % with the STY of 51.9 μmol·g−1·min−1. In combination to CO2-TPD, it is deduced that the decreased activity after coating with TiO2 might be attributed to reduction of medium-strong basic sites. Acid and base density was calculated based on NH3– and CO2-TPD results to further correlate the catalytic performance with acid-base properties. As seen in Table S10, after coating with TiO2, the acid-base density of the catalyst increases. NSC-Ti/P-0.5-TiO2-0.075 shows the highest density of acid, while NSC-Ti/P-0.6-TiO2-0.075 shows the highest density of base. Zuo et al.[21,39], concluded that the synergetic effects between BAS and LAS can exert good catalytic capacity, regulating acidity is crucial to achieving a suitable B/L ratio, essential for enhancing the formation of target products. It is found from Py-IR result that the addition of TiO2 induces increase in the amount of both BAS and LAS, which might be due to protective effect of TiO2 coating on unsaturated Ti species on the catalyst surface [40]. Otherwise, basic sites especially moderately-strong basic sites, are able to activate acetic acid through interaction with α-H on it to form carbanion, which easily reacts with formaldehyde adsorbed on catalyst via nucleophilic addition reactions, thus, the new C–C bond will be created. The above indicates that the synergetic effects of acidic and basic sites are crucial to the aldol condensation of formaldehyde and acetic acid. Single type acidity or basicity does not decide the catalyst performance [13]. Higher density of acid and base and appropriate ratio between them are conducive to generating a matching number of active intermediates, thereby promoting the formation of more target products. In combination of Table S5, it is plausible that STY of acrylic acid and methyl acrylate is more related to amount of acidic and basic sites. 3.2.4 Catalyst durability and characterization of spent catalysts In our experiment, it was found that the catalyst became black color after 2 h reaction. In order to learn the possible reason for catalyst deactivation. Here, the NSC Ti/P-0.5-TiO2-0.075 catalyst spent for 2 h was characterized using XRD and TG techniques. As show in Figure S6a, there is no significant change in the crystal structure of the material after 2 h reaction (from curves B and C). In addition, after the spent catalyst was regenerated under air atmosphere via calcination at 490 °C, the regenerated sample still shows original crystal structure (curve D in Figure S6a). Further, TG measurement (Figure S6b) reveals that the DTG curve of the catalyst after the reaction only has an exothermic peak near 440 °C, which is related with the first-order weight loss change in its TG curve. Based on the above, it is concluded that the catalyst deactivation is mainly caused by carbon deposition. In order to understand the catalyst durability, the reaction over NSC-Ti/P-0.6-TiO2-0.075 was run for a period of 50 h. As shown in the Figure S7, the selectivity of MA+AA decreases from 50.9 % at the initial stage to 32.4 % after 50 h (based on Eq. (4)), where, the fluctuation is mainly attributed to the differences in the selectivity of acetate methyl ester formed. Further conducting a detailed analysis based on the data obtained from Eq. (3), it (the blue line in Figure S7) reveals that the catalyst activity rapidly decreases within the initial 15 h, and subsequently become stable. Generally, the acid-base sites on the catalyst easily lead to the carbon deposition. Therefore, it is deduced that the deposited carbon was rapidly formed at the initial stage. By the way, though the TiO2-coated NASICON catalyst shows deactivation, TiO2 as redox active phase should also play a certain positive effect on the alleviation of carbon deposition under air atmosphere. 3.3 Investigation on catalytic mechanism 3.3.1 In-situ DRIFT To gain insights into the two-step reaction for converting methanol and acetic acid to acrylic acid, in-situ DRIFT experiments were employed to investigate the adsorption and activation of these reactants on the catalyst surface. Fig. 10 a presents in-situ DRIFT spectra of the catalyst after achieving saturation with acetic acid adsorption. Referring to absorption status on KBr, the vibration peaks at 1797 cm−1 and 1778 cm−1 are ascribed to carbonyl vibrations of the gas-phase acetic acid, and the one at 1683 cm−1 is associated with the surface acetyl carbonyl vibrations known as acetic acid dissociative adsorption [39]. On single NASICON sample, acetic acid is mainly dominated as gas-phase adsorption on the surface and the chemisorption has an increasing trend with the increase of Ti/P ratio. However, in the case of the catalysts with TiO2 coating, the chemisorption of acetic acid is enhanced, which is consistent with the change of basic property. In the following operation, Ar was used to purge the catalyst saturated with acetic acid and the spectra were recorded with purging time, as shown in Fig. 10d1-d6 (the arrows in the figure indicate the increase of purge time). From Fig. 10d1-d6, it is plausible that the adsorption of acetic acid on each catalyst decreases with the purge time. Thereinto, gas-phase adsorption is unstable and weakens rapidly, while chemisorption is relatively stable. Further, the peaks for dissociative adsorption on NSC-Ti/P-0.5 and NSC-Ti/P-0.5-TiO2-0.075 catalysts decrease rapidly with the purge time; conversely, those on NSC-Ti/P-0.6, NSC-Ti/P-0.7, NSC-Ti/P-0.6-TiO2-0.075, and NSC-Ti/P-0.7-TiO2-0.075 catalysts decrease slowly. After purging Ar, the vibration peaks generated by gas-phase and chemical adsorption on the NSC-Ti/P-0.6-TiO2-0.075 catalyst attenuate slowly, comparing to that on the NSC-Ti/P-0.5-TiO2-0.075 catalyst. This implies that the moderate adsorption strength of acetic acid on the catalyst is conducive to its activation. The effects of TiO2 coating on the performance of methanol dehydrogenation were also investigated through in-situ DRIFT experiment. After introducing methanol into in-situ cell through carrier gas: air, IR spectra were collected, as shown in Fig. 10b and c. Here, the peaks at 2981 cm−1 and 2865 cm−1 are ascribed to the ν(CH3) vibration of gas-phase methanol [41]. From Fig. 10b, there is no obvious difference in vibration band for the catalysts. The peaks below 1700 cm−1 are further amplified and shown in Fig. 10c, where the peak at 1623 cm−1 is attributed to the ν(C = O) vibration of formaldehyde (CH2O*) [42]. For single NSC-Ti/P-x samples, weak vibration peaks of formaldehyde adsorption are presented. In the case of the NSC-Ti/P-x-TiO2-0.075 samples, the vibration peaks are obviously enhanced. Since CH2O* is produced via sequential dehydrogenation of methanol [43,44], the enhancement of the vibrational peaks means the relatively good dehydrogenation activity of the catalyst. This indicates that the introduced TiO2 certainly exerts a positive effect on methanol dehydrogenation. Further, it is noted that NSC-Ti/P-0.6-TiO2-0.075 shows the highest peak of formaldehyde adsorption, indicating its best activity of dehydrogenation. The previous catalyst evaluation has showed that NSC-Ti/P-0.6-TiO2-0.075 has best performance in acrylic acid synthesis. It is apparently plausible that the methanol dehydrogenation is remarkably crucial. Factually, from by-products listed in Table S1, it is also noted that the formaldehyde selectivity is improved with TiO2 coating. 3.3.2 Possible reaction route for AA formation Investigation on the roles of different catalytic sites is necessary to understand catalytic mechanism. As demonstrated previously by us, NASICON material possesses redox capacity after coating TiO2. In order to investigate whether the redox reaction of methanol occurs on the TiO2 surface or on the NASICON surface, pure TiO2 prepared by us was used to catalyze the dehydrogenation of methanol under air atmosphere and the results are given in Table S11. It is observed that methanol conversion reaches up to 77.7 % on the pure TiO2, and most of methanol is converted to DME (selectivity of 33.3 %), formaldehyde (6.34 %), COx (34.4 %) and CH4 (8.4 %), which is similar with that of commercial P25 TiO2. This indicates that TiO2 possesses good oxidation ability with the presence of oxygen. Our previous result has revealed that there is no acrylic acid and methyl acrylate produced on the pure TiO2. It proves that TiO2 has good redox properties, but is invalid for aldol condensation, probably ascribing to the lack of acidic and basic sites. Further, SiO2-coated NASICON catalyst, which was synthesized using similar method with TiO2-coated catalyst preparation, was used for direct conversion of methanol and acetic acid. The result revealed that acrylic acid and methyl acrylate are hardly formed on the SiO2-coated NASICON catalyst; instead, the methyl acetate and DME are two main products. This certainly indicates that the introduced TiO2 indeed exerts redox effect. As aforementioned, the single NASICON material shows poor performance for methanol and acetic acid conversion into acrylic acid. However, by constructing a new catalyst comprised with TiO2 and NASICON material with an appropriate ratio, acrylic acid production is able to be realized. Thereinto, TiO2 coating provides good and mild redox ability to produce formaldehyde intermediates, while NASICON material provides suitable acid-base sites to facilitate the activation of formaldehyde and acetic acid to produce the target product, as discussed previously. The synergistic effects of the two components (TiO2 and NASICON) are complementary, ensuring the smooth proceeding of the reaction. Herein, we propose a possible reaction route for direct synthesis of acrylic acid on the TiO2-coated NASICON catalyst. As shown in Fig. 11 , methanol is oxidized on TiO2 to generate formaldehyde, and then, formaldehyde is activated to carbocation at the BAS on the surface of NASICON. Simultaneously, acetic acid is activated on the basic sites and LAS to form α-c anions [39,45]. For this step, a suitable proportion of B/L and a certain amount of medium strong basic sites are required to execute the formation of active intermediates. Subsequently, the carbanion of acetic acid reacts with the carbocation of formaldehyde to form an intermediate aldehyde via the nucleophilic addition reaction, which is ultimately dehydrated to form acrylic acid. In addition, the methyl acetic formed on acidic sites is also activated, and further connected with the activated formaldehyde to form methyl acrylate as shown in Fig. 11. Otherwise, there exists reversible conversion between acrylic acid and methyl acrylate in the present system. One should bear in mind that the performance of the NASICON material with TiO2 coating for acrylic acid synthesis from methanol and acetic acid are the synactic outcomes caused by different active sites. Nonetheless, this complex system needs to be further studied in the next work to understand the catalytic mechanism in-depth. 4 Conclusion In this study, NASICON material substrate prepared by sol–gel method was coated with TiO2 through the hydrolysis of TBOT to fabricate the bi-functional catalyst with redox and aldol condensation capacities. This is the first attempt that NASICON catalyst system catalyzes condensation of methanol and acetic acid into acrylic acid. It has been demonstrated that the coating NASICON with TiO2 is an effective strategy. The selectivity of AA+MA as high as 56.1 % is achieved at 380 °C on the designed catalyst, with the STY of 46.5 μmol·g−1·min−1. The characterizations of XRD, SEM, HRTEM and N2 adsorption reveal that TiO2 coating layer has minor effect on the structural morphology of the NASICON substrate. XPS results reveal that TiO2 coating induces the shift of Ti2p BEs to lower position and the increase of the proportion of Ti3+ species, which is likely to play a redox role in methanol dehydrogenation into formaldehyde. Acid-base characterizations indicate that TiO2 coating is able to regulate the acid-base properties of the catalyst to a certain extent, behaving that activity of aldol condensation is slightly weakened. In-situ DRIFT results and the evaluation for methanol dehydrogenation on pure TiO2 further demonstrate that the catalysts with TiO2 coating indeed show obviously enhanced capacity for dehydrogenation of methanol. With efficient synergy of redox and acid-base properties, the direct synthesis of acrylic acid and methyl acrylate has been realized successfully. The present study provides an alternative strategy for the design of efficient catalyst for similar cascade reaction. coredata.dc:description: Direct conversion of methanol and acetic acid (HAc) into acrylic acid (AA) and methyl acrylate (MA) is remarkably significant for the high-value utilization of coal-based chemicals. However, the previous catalysts, due to their single function or poor synergy between multiple active sites, remain large challenges in direct synthesis of acrylic acid. Herein, we designed a novel catalyst system through coating TiO2 to sodium superionic conductor (NASICON) substrate for direct synthesis of acrylic acid from methanol and acetic acid. It was revealed that the catalyst with TiO2 coating showed obviously improved performance. The selectivity of AA+MA highly reached 56.1 % at 380 °C, corresponding to the spatiotemporal yield of 46.5 μmol·g−1·min−1. It was demonstrated that TiO2 coating catalyzes the oxidative dehydrogenation of methanol to formaldehyde, while NASICON substrate exerts important effects on the aldol condensation of formaldehyde and acetic acid, and their effective synergy promotes the direct synthesis of acrylic acid.
